headline.main: BOSTON FANS' HOPE HAS A BITTER EDGE

byline.original: By MICHAEL GOODWIN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: SENDING a baseball player down to the minor leagues is usually a routine matter. But when the Boston Red Sox shipped a rookie named Pumpsie Green to their Minneapolis farm team in 1959, it caused an uproar. The local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. called the move ''outrageous,'' and team officials were called to testify before the state commission against discrimination. Whether Green had the talent to play in the big time was almost beside the point. He was black, and the decision to farm him out meant that the Red Sox, the last all-white team in the major leagues, would remain segregated at least a while longer. Green eventually made his debut that July, 12 years after Jackie Robinson broke baseball's color line. But the team's racial problems did not magically end. For the past 40 years the Red Sox, more than any other club, have remained dogged by charges of discrimination. And now, following the dismissal of the club's only black coach, the issue has been raised yet again.

headline.main: BOSTON CASE REVIVES PAST AND PASSIONS

docs.lead_paragraph: THE message taped to the back of his locker told as much as anything else about the ballplayer's dedication. ''In box with left leg and all weight on it,'' the note read. ''Nothing on front leg. WAIT.'' Below that were scrawled the words ''Stay Back'' and ''Relax.'' Could this be the urgent reminder of a promising rookie left-handed hitter brought up to the big club for a late-season audition? Not exactly. Carl Yastrzemski was a major league rookie in 1961, the year he replaced Ted Williams as left fielder for the Boston Red Sox.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mickey Mantle, Billy Martin and Whitey Ford were in Winnipeg night before last for a fund-raising affair for a youth movement and one of them said: "Tomorrow is Bob Fishel's 65th birthday. Some of the writers are throwing a surprise luncheon for him in New York." "What the hell," one of the others said: "let's go."

A Flag for Betsy Ross's Town?

docs.lead_paragraph: If New York City had any class it would start paying Catfish Hunter's salary without another day's delay. The Cat is one of the chief drawing cards the city is relying on to boost Yankee Stadium attendance to 2 million next summer and thus enable the taxpayers to get some return on their $75 million investment in the park.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jim Hunter is about the size of a large millionaire. Like most of the men who played with him for the Oakland A's, he is fairly hairy, with a coiffure that overhangs his ears like a thatched roof and an upper lip likely to attract a pair of indigo buntings at nesting time.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a year he says will be his last, Ortiz is playing like a superstar half his age.
docs.abstract: David Ortiz, at age 40, has been performing like superstar half his age in what he says is his final season with Boston Red Sox; leads majors in slugging percentage and is hitting .339.
